ul.li1: 171 Better a dry morsel and quiet with it
ul.li2: than a house filled with feasts of strife.
ul.li1: 2A slave who deals wisely will rule over a child who acts shamefully,
ul.li2: and in the midst of brothers he will share his inheritance.
ul.li1: 3A crucible is for the silver, and a furnace is for the gold,
ul.li2: but Yahweh will test hearts.
ul.li1: 4He who does evil listens to lips of wickedness,
ul.li2: and the liar gives heed to the tongue of mischief.
ul.li1: 5He who mocks the poor insults him who made him;
ul.li2: he who rejoices at calamity will not go unpunished.
ul.li1: 6The crown of the elderly are grandchildren,Literally “sons of sons”
ul.li2: and the glory of children is their fathers.
ul.li1: 7Fine speechLiterally “A lip of fineness” is not becoming a fool,
ul.li2: still lessLiterally “only for” is false speechLiterally “lip of deceit” for a ruler.
ul.li1: 8The bribe is a stone of magic in the eyes of its owner;Or “master”
ul.li2: everywhereLiterally “to all which” he will turn, he will prosper.
ul.li1: 9He who forgives an affront fosters love,
ul.li2: but he who waits on a matter will alienate a friend.
ul.li1: 10A rebuke strikes him who understands
ul.li2: deeper than one hundred blows to a fool.
ul.li1: 11An evil person will seek only rebellion,
ul.li2: and a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
ul.li1: 12May a man meet a she-bear robbed of offspring
ul.li2: and not a fool in his folly.
ul.li1: 13For he who returns evil for good,
ul.li2: evil will not depart from his house.
ul.li1: 14Like the release of water is the beginning of strife;
ul.li2: before it breaks out, stop the quarrel.
ul.li1: 15He who justifies the wicked and he who condemns the righteous,
ul.li2: the two of them are both abominations of Yahweh.
ul.li1: 16Why is this? A price in the hand of a fool,
ul.li2: in order to buy wisdom whereHebrew “and” there is no sense.Literally “heart”
ul.li1: 17The friend loves at all timesHebrew “time”,
ul.li2: but a brother is born for adversity.
ul.li1: 18A person who lacks senseLiterally “heart” pledges;Literally “pledges a hand”
ul.li2: he becomes security before his neighbor.
ul.li1: 19He who loves transgression loves strife;
ul.li2: he who builds his high thresholds seeks destruction.
ul.li1: 20He who is crooked of heartOr “mind” will not find goodness,
ul.li2: and he who is perverse, by his tongue he will fall into calamity.
ul.li1: 21He who begets a fool, there is trouble for him;
ul.li2: the father of a fool will not rejoice.
ul.li1: 22A cheerful heart is good medicine,
ul.li2: but a downcast spirit will dry out bones.
ul.li1: 23The wicked will accept a bribe from the lap,
ul.li2: in order to pervert the ways of justice.
ul.li1: 24He who understands sets his face toward wisdom,
ul.li2: but the eyes of a fool, to the end of the earth.Or “land”
ul.li1: 25A grief to his father is the child of a fool,
ul.li2: and bitterness to her who bore him.
ul.li1: 26Also, imposing a fine on the righteous is not good,
ul.li2: nor to flog nobles for uprightness.
ul.li1: 27He who spares his sayings knows knowledge,
ul.li2: and a cool spirit is a man of understanding.
ul.li1: 28Even a fool who keeps silent shall be considered wise;Literally “wise, he shall be considered”
ul.li2: he who closes his lips is intelligent.
